documents.commentText:
The following is an anecdotal report of my own experience with Kratom. 

Kratom is the common name for the species of plant that is scientifically known as "mitragyna speciosa". The chemical that gives the plant its main effects is the chemical "mitragynine"

Mitragynine is what is known as an opioid, it acts upon opioid receptors in the brain, however, I must note that mitragynine is what is known as an atypical opioid, and that it is not an opiate. Opiates, by definition, are chemicals that are derived from and have the same basic carbon backbone structure as morphine. So all opiates are opioids, but all opioids are not opiates.

It also needs to be noted that I personally have an affinity for all opioids, have tried many different opioids, so therefore even though my experience is anecdotal and provides zero statistical data, it also means that I'm in a position to accurately describe the subtle differences in mitragynine and other opioids. However, it must also be remembered that if opioids are my drug of  choice, it is because my brain at sometime in the past, changed due to neuroplasticity in such a way to have a high affinity for opioids, which gives my experience a bit of bias. 

The main, core reasons I had for using kratom was for mood enhancement, I also enjoyed things better when I would take kratom, such as watching movies or playing videogames. Kratom made work a lot more tolerable.

The first time I heard about kratom was back in 2008, however, I did not try it until 2013. The first time I tried it I hadn't used any opioid in a long time, to me the effects felt like taking around 30mg of oxycodone. 

Tolerance to kratom develops rapidly and for me seemed to level out at around a maximum of 60g a day, after that there was a euphoric ceiling effect, unlike substances such as heroin or oxycodone, which have no euphoric ceiling effect.

I have currently been using kratom almost everyday for around a year. I already have anxiety issues and depression issues, and I most certainly used kratom to deal with them, because it worked. But there is a huge issue of diminishing returns. For me, once I developed a tolerance to kratom, I also became physically addicted, it felt like I could not get through the day without kratom, currently I have come to realize that a lot of the physical withdrawal from kratom is psychosomatic, the physical withdrawal from kratom is nothing compared to heroin or methadone withdrawal, but it is there. The psychological withdrawal is just as bad if not even a little worse with kratom than with other opioids like lortab or percocet. My theory is because kratom is illegal, when you do start feeling withdrawal it's easy to convince oneself that it is ok to go to the smoke shop and get some kratom, it's accessible, but it is also NOT CHEAP. 

Another thing to remember is that mitragynine not only acts on mu opioid receptors like oxycodone and morphine, but it also acts on delta and kappa opioid receptors, this has its own problems that are very complex.

Now I know there was a lot of public outcry about the ban of kratom that was to happen on September 30th and this is why it was postponed, but I was disappointed when the ban didn't happen. I have been trying to free myself of this substance for months now and my thought was, "Now I won't be able to obtain it and withdrawal is going to be a lot easier!". The ban did not go through and I still use kratom, albeit less than I have in the past. I do however realize that I should be able to stop without it being illegal if I have enough willpower, but then we'd need to get in to how addictive drugs work in the first place and this paper would be a huge wall of text. 

I think the scheduling system that the DEA uses for substances is counter intuitive and allows for substances to be wrongly classified. I do not think that kratom is a schedule 1 substance, just like I don't think cannabis and by extension THC is a schedule 1 substance. I don't even think diacytlmorphine (heroin) is a schedule 1 substance, it has medical use and is used in Europe.

I think the fact that the above mentioned chemicals are schedule 1 yet methamphetamine and cocaine remain schedule 2 is ridiculous.

The point of this letter is to let you know that kratom is addictive, it is an opioid and I myself continue to struggle with it like someone may struggle with caffeine or nicotine addiction. The DEA in general needs a new classification system for substances, especially since now over half the country will soon have access to recreational marijuana.

This letter was written in haste, I did not know this site was here and the deadline existed until today. I realize my letter bounces around a lot and reads choppy, I would love if you would contact me so I could give my experience in better detail.

documents.commentText:
Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, as they occur naturally in the leaves of Mitragyna speciosa (kratom), are useful in the treatment of opioid dependency.

Kratom is used by countless addicts across the United States as a replacement for the opioids on which they would otherwise remain dependent. In many cases, they will then discontinue their use of kratom as well; it then becomes a "reverse gateway" back to sobriety.

In other cases, its use is continued long-term. This is still a very positive outcome. Kratom is safer than any true opioid, while acting just strongly enough on the opioid receptors to keep withdrawal symptoms at bay. There has never been a recorded death due to overdose on kratom alone; the same cannot be said of methadone, which is used extensively as a legal replacement therapy for opioid addiction.

It makes no sense to schedule kratom, and in so doing, take this tool away from people who seek to reduce their suffering. The predictable outcome of kratom prohibition will be an increase in the already high rate of addiction to prescription narcotic pain relievers, heroin, and other dangerous drugs.

Science and history show that drug addiction is a health problem most effectively addressed through systems of social support and appropriate medical care. Criminalizing addicts' behavior--especially when that behavior is likely to improve their condition--is contrary to the goals of public safety and public health.

I am a practicing herbalist and professional member of the American Herbalists Guild (AHG), a non-profit, educational, member-based association of herbal practitioners founded to represent the goals and voices of herbalists specializing in the medicinal use of plants. 

I am opposed to the classification of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine as Schedule I substances according to the Controlled Substances Act (CSA)  a regulatory move that would effectively ban the plant kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) which contains these constituents.

The AHG, and myself, consider such a step to be unjustified.  As noted by AHPA and others, there is no precedent for the DEA to use its emergency authority in this manner for a naturally occurring substance such as a plant.  As documented elsewhere (Yearsley, McGuffin and Young) the serious adverse health effects including deaths that have been in some cases potentially attributed to kratom are more likely due to adulteration and/or concomitant use of hazardous and toxic substances.

Schedule I classification would also be highly counterproductive in terms of gaining additional scientific knowledge about kratom and its potential uses, as well any potential safety concerns, in that such a legal classification would overly restrict further scientific research into not only its safety but also its therapeutic value.

The AHG urges the DEA to permanently set aside the potential classification of kratom as a Schedule I drug as inappropriate, given all we know of its uses and safety based on both science and tradition.  We believe that it is vital that plants with a long tradition of therapeutic use such as kratom remain accessible to the public.

Thank you for your time and attention,
Jillian Bar-av

To Whom it May Concern:

My name is Keoni Lima, a 38-year old single parent, judo coach for USA Judo, and a corporate manager for a nationwide payroll software firm.  Prior to working in the private sector, I was a police officer and an enlisted member of the United States Army Reserve.

I am writing these comments to express my strong opposition of the DEA's proposed ban on the alkaloids found within the holistic natural supplement called Kratom.  Not only do I believe this proposed ban to be overreach of the DEA's powers, I believe it is unwarranted and reckless. 

I began using Kratom is 2012 when I was introduced to it by a holistic health practitioner who was assisting me in my physical therapy and recovery from a severe motorcycle accident in 2011.  After 14-months of being in a wheelchair and coping with a 27-pin external fixator, I needed to find a natural remedy to help me transition from dangerous prescribed pain medications, and their associated debilitating side-effects.

Since using kratom in 2012, I was able to stop the use of all prescribed pain medications.  I was able to complete my 24-month physical therapy program, and find the energy and drive to learn to walk and run again. Moreover, I did not experience the dangerous side-effects that I regularly experienced with prescribed pain medications, such as drowsiness, constipation, nausea, itching, fatigue, confusion, weight gain or fatigue.  Kratom gave me a sense of well-being, while working effectively to give me the energy that I needed to work through my physical therapy program.

That said, never once have I been 'high' or 'intoxicated' from kratom.  It has never caused me unpleasant, uncontrollable, euphoric, or dangerous side-effects.  As a daily user of kratom, I am proud at the fact that I can easily stop my kratom use at anytime, and not experience the profound withdrawals that are seen within many other natural and prescribed substances.  In fact, I am so confident in it's safety, I openly shared it with my 68-year old cancer patient mother, who has taken kratom for the last year to naturally help alleviate the fatigue and discomfort associated with radiation and chemotherapy treatments.

To close, kratom has been legally consumed and utilized by people in the United States for several decades. In comparison to other over-the-counter drugs (i.e. Tylenol, caffeine, etc.) or natural supplements (i.e. iron, St. Johns Wart, energy drinks, etc.), it has an amazingly safe track record.  I implore the United States DEA, to view kratom as the safe and natural holistic supplement that it is, and cease any and all efforts to list the alkaloids within kratom as scheduled drugs within the United States.

Please don't take another natural supplement that has so many lifelong benefits away from the people.

Please act in the interest of public good and keep kratom available. Listen to the words of the people.

documents.commentText:
Kratom may be safer and less addictive than current treatments for pain, research suggests
Published on November 29, 2016 at 1:07 PM  No Comments

inShare
Share
 
A delayed U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration ban on kratom would stifle scientific understanding of the herb's active chemical components and documented pharmacologic properties if implemented, according to a special report published today in The Journal of the American Osteopathic Association.

The report cited the pharmacologically active compounds in kratom, including mitragynine, 7-hydroxymitragynine, paynantheine, speciogynine and 20 other substances, as one basis for further study. It also emphasized the extensive amount of anecdotal evidence and current scientific research that indicates kratom may be safer and less addictive than current treatments for pain and opioid withdrawal.

"There's no question kratom compounds have complex and potential useful pharmacologic activities and they produce chemically different actions from opioids," said author Walter Prozialeck, chairman of the Department of Pharmacology at Midwestern University Chicago College of Osteopathic Medicine. "Kratom doesn't produce an intense euphoria and, even at very high doses, it doesn't depress respiration, which could make it safer for users."

Related Stories
Identifying foods that trigger IBS: an interview with Dr Bill Chey
U-M investigators awarded $7.5 million NIH grant to expand chronic pain research
Many back pain patients taking opioids get limited relief and worry about side effects, study finds
Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) is indigenous to Southeast Asia, where the plant was used for centuries to relieve fatigue, pain, cough and diarrhea and aid in opioid withdrawal. Currently sold in the United States as an herbal supplement, kratom drew DEA scrutiny after poison control centers noted 660 reports of adverse reactions to kratom products between January 2010 and December 2015.

"Many important medications, including the breast cancer treatment tamoxifen, were developed from plant research," said Prozialeck.

"While the DEA and physicians have valid safety concerns, it is not at all clear that kratom is the culprit behind the adverse effects," said Anita Gupta, DO, PharmD and special advisor to the FDA.

Dr. Gupta, an osteopathic anesthesiologist, pain specialist and licensed pharmacist, has treated a number of patients who've used kratom. "Many of my patients are seeking non-pharmaceutical remedies to treat pain that lack the side effects, risk, and addiction potential of opioids," she said.

Kratom is currently banned in states including Alabama, Florida, Indiana, Arkansas, Wisconsin and Tennessee. The DEA is scheduled to decide whether to place kratom on its list of Schedule 1 drugs, a classification for compounds thought to have no known medical benefit. Marijuana, LSD and heroin are Schedule 1 drugs, which prevents the vast majority of U.S.-based researchers from studying those substances

Many people do not realize that people with bipolar are more likely than the general population to experience certain types of chronic, physical pain. Fatigue, headaches, and insomnia are just a few of the side affects of mental illness, and when I say fatigue, I dont mean the groggy feeling a coffee will fix in the morning. When I say fatigue, I mean feeling tired down to the bone, tired to the point where it is difficult to even think about leaving the house. Migraines become a daily battle that lead me into a cycle of isolation and depression and begin to infringe on my personal and professional life. Insomnia also begins to slowly take a toll after weeks on end. Chronic pain is difficult to deal with even when a person is otherwise healthy. Adding pain to a debilitating illness like bipolar disorder can make even the best of us feel hopeless. 

I was diagnosed with bipolar disorder at age 16 and spent the next few years playing the game of which doctor? What medication? At what dosage? There were so many side affects and the time that it took to find the  doses that worked led me to a place of static dissonance that no amount of exercise, therapy or mindfulness could defeat.  I felt completely out of touch with my own mind and the sense of control over my life diminished significantly as the medications began to take their toll. I slowly began to lose hope and spiraled into a 5 year long depression using drugs and alcohol as a way to cope with my deteriorating mental state. You see, people with mood disorders tend to experience the world loudly. This is a kind of exaggerated perception that exists on both of the positive and negative emotional and mental poles.  During a manic episode, life is more colorful and vivid, I become utterly in awe of a sunset, or a beautiful tree, everyday benign things become larger than life.  Even the good and stable things in my life can become distorted. When I see the man I am going to marry, I am overwhelmed with emotion. Everything is all at once too much, too loud. And when depression strikes, the loudness is just them same. A small setback becomes a complete catastrophe in my mind. Something as minor as being cut off while driving can enrage me to no end and stick with me more than it should.

Once I began supplementing Kratom tea into my daily routine of running, yoga and meditation, I immediately noticed minimizing effects of cognitive dissonance, the absence of panic attacks and the impact of lowering my depressive obsession. With Kratom, I slowly began to turn around to more frequent and longer sustained times of calmness, clarity and pain relief regardless of any difficult situation. Being able to think clearly for the first time in over a decade allowed me the extra psychological and physical space to go to work and function as a happy, healthy individual. To me, Kratom became a supporting element of self discipline that built resolve and a more solid sense of accomplishment. 

I am a daughter and soon to be wife. My family depends on my being well to take care of them and do my part. I can absolutely live my life while still battling this disorder, but, to put it bluntly, it will be MUCH harder. Yes, there are others with bipolar who are in much more pain than I who face it every single day, even now. But, the utter unfairness of being robbed of a benign, harmless plant with so many positive and effective properties is inhumane and unnecessary. I will survive and I will manage but it will be in pain and with much distress. To be forced back into the guessing game of figuring out which medication may help this week, or perhaps something new with a whole host of ill side effects that may not work at all is daunting. Medications that I cannot afford, doctors visits that I cannot afford. All of which make me feel as though Im back at square one. 

Allowing the DEA to place Kratom as a Schedule 1 drug is extreme, unfounded, and overreaching. Scheduling it this way will prevent science from studying its effects in a medical setting. I can admit that Kratom should in fact be studied. The side effects and health risks should be understood. But how can we allow the DEA to place a blanket ban on something that is clearly so helpful to thousands of people? Those of us with bipolar have the same human and democratic rights as those without. We deserve options that work, and that help us keep it together. Life is harder for us than it is for others. We have to struggle to just achieve a baseline. How can you say that something that so obviously works is an evil? We are human beings who simply want our lives back, and this overreach of federal power feels like a boot stepping down on helpless ants. Uncaring, unaware, unsympathetic.

Kratom should not be banned.  It should either remain as it has been, available to consumers and researchers laissez-faire, or regulated as beverage tea is, or as an OTC supplement. Abundantly clear after  objective analysis is that kratom is a safe and beneficial herb that offers far more good than harm, and that the relatively few who abuse the herb  number a small fraction of the many who receive great benefit.    In short, the real situation is not even remotely a "public health emergency". If anything public health is winning (finally!) by a knowing acceptance of kratom, as more and more people find their way out of the dangerous and debilitating opiate epidemic, and let's not forget productivity-ending chronic pain and anxiety syndromes. People know this.
So, with all due respect, if the Agencies that determine policy want to put a final nail in the coffin of their credibility in this particular arena, banning kratom is a great way to do it. The DEA in particular has been doubling down on it's "marijuana" propaganda in the many years overwhelming evidence has shown it to be just that (counterfactual propaganda), and We The People know it.  Very little public support for the War On Drugs remains, and banning kratom is an obvious expansion of the same failed policies. The Public is saying: "Wait..let me get this straight...you want EXPAND misguided policies?" Searching for a reason for the obvious cognitive dissonance, We The People see a money motive, and we are not likely wrong. Lobbies. Can't live with 'em, can't...well, never say never.

Here's the truth: people are born of nature, and nature is the premiere apothecary. There was a great article by Dr Andrew Weil featured in the Huffington Post recently that makes the case: Why Plants Are (Usually) Better Than Drugs. The article outlines  rational reasons why this is true, to date. Dr Weil's assertion: " the fact is, the natural, whole plant often has both benefits and safety that put the isolated compounds to shame." The reason is found in knowledge of systems: a complex of compounds  will engage a more dynamic equilibrium of homeostatic mechanisms than will compound isolates. That dynamism yields therapeutic sophistication. 

Thousands of testimonials give empirical weight to the premise: herbs work far better in many cases than drugs. For example, people very often use the word "godsend" when describing the difference kratom has made for them, after describing how miserably drugs failed them in their pursuit of well-being.   

So, Dr. Weil's article touches on the rational, scientific case for a far more laissez-faire approach to herbs. There is also the case that invokes our philosophy of Rights:  personal liberty, cognitive liberty, and  religious liberty. 

Personal liberty is the general pursuit of happiness Right. If I harm no one in it, I have the right to pursue well-being as I see fit. Cognitive liberty is the right to determine my own consciousness in my own way. No one, martini in hand, has the moral high ground to wag a finger, let alone ban, my use of a plant to alter my own consciousness. And finally, religious liberty:   more and more Americans identify as "spiritual but not religious". Yet legal precedence allows religious exemption to prohibited substance penalties only to historically validated traditions, such as Native American Church -"Peyotism", and even then it has been a hard-fought battle. The point is, many Americans and people the world over believe that herbs are "wise" medicines from a Creator and/or Nature, and so greatly prefer them   to invented or isolated compounds (and as Dr Weil's article suggests, it is not an irrational preference). Yet they will  have a hard time getting the Courts to protect that sincere spiritual lifestyle preference under religious freedom; does it make sense that that should that be the case?
 My position:
We need to Make Liberty Great Again. No more bans. Ban banning.

To whom it may concern:

I'm writing to offer my  experiences with Kratom products.  I first tried Kratom a couple years ago while I was suffering from moderate to severe right shoulder pain that had persisted for months.  I self-treated with OTC NSAIDs and immobilization,  I also visited an Orthopedic provider who offered me Rx NSAIDs, opiates and expensive injections.  I chose to stick with OTC relief rather than risk an addiction to hydrocodone.  

Shortly after my trip to the physician, a gas station attendant told me about a 2 oz drink that some said helped their pain.  Well, I tried it.  It did help, but it was not like taking a 'REAL' opiate.  I'd taken an opiate twice -- Once for a chronic cough in syrup form, and once in pill form for a kidney stone. There was no comparison in potency, analgesic effect, euphoria or side effects.  Because it was somewhat effective, I bought quite a lot.  I even tried it in pill form and tea.  I used it daily for several months while my pain persisted.

While I was using Kratom, I monitored myself.   I was nervous from bad press here in Alabama where it has since been banned.  I am a Medical Technologist turned healthcare IT professional, and have the ability to check my blood work and vitals any time I wish.  My blood chemistry tests, including liver function and cholesterol, and blood counts were unchanged from my normals, and my blood pressure was not affected.   

Withdrawal did exist, but it was very mild.  I skipped several days of treatment during the months I used Kratom, and I did notice I would be cranky almost like I hadn't had enough coffee on the days I didn't use any. It wasn't nearly as bad as skipping my morning coffee though.   If you're a coffee drinker and have skipped your daily dose, you know the pain!  It took me days of awful withdrawal symptoms to kick my two cup per day coffee habit after my college days.  I'm back on that wagon in full force now though.  The withdrawal symptoms I had when I stopped Kratom lasted a single day, and it was simply that I felt a little thick-headed and mildly cranky.

Based on my experience with the product, I think it's proper to continue treating it like other herbal supplements.  I realize my experience is only one anecdote, but the nearly non-existent withdrawal and unchanged medical assessments make me feel like the concern about this product is overblown.   I understand the concern because it's thought to bind with opiate receptors, but, again, there is no comparison to Rx opiates.  I can compare it to Valerian root for sleep.  Valerian is thought to act on GABA receptors like Benzos or sedative hypnotics, but there is really no comparison.  

I can't help but wonder what would happen if coffee or tea had been a recent market in the U.S.   Of course, this is not the case, but hypothetically, you guys would be quite concerned about the dependence, irregular heart beats and deaths that occur from caffeine consumption if these products were somewhat new here.  I'd bet statistically, caffeine's adverse side effects  have a higher representation per user in emergency rooms than Kratom's.  How many cases of palpitations, tachycardia and angina in emergency rooms could be avoided if people cut or avoid  their caffeine consumption?  

 Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

My name is Brian and I'm a 20 year old Student at the University of Delaware. I imagine my comment, if read, will be echoing the same sentiments as many others belonging to a long list of kratom users. I'm sure I don't need to rehash all the numerous arguments in favor of kratom's legality, nor do I need to remind you of the plant's negative potential. I can only assume that the reader of this comment will be far too aware that kratom is "not a drug," or "totally natural, man." Instead, it is my intention to shed light on what may be a less than usual argument and illustrate what is, in my opinion, the real problem. 

I in fact, have never used kratom; neither recreationally nor therapeutically. I am however a friend to enough heroin and pill addicts to fill up at least one hand. I am a boyfriend to a girl who lost her brother to a legal prescription opiate addiction. I have born witness to more drug related tragedies than I care to recount. And most importantly, I am not even close to being unique. Indeed, today's America is now one where the minority are those that haven't been affected --either directly or indirectly-- by opiate addiction. 

Now, to clarify, I do not live on the wrong side of the tracks. I am far from underprivledged, and I have a loving home with excellent parents. In high school I was an honors student, varsity wrestling, student paper editing, straight A getting, model student. I didn't have a bad group of friends. I didn't loiter in alleyways or street corners. I never so much as got a detention. 

Yet, not even a kid with as perfect an upbringing as mine could stay completely away from the affect of legal and illegal opiates. Before I was out of high school I had been offered percocet, vicodin, and oxycotin among other things. I didn't take those drugs, but the decision to say no was one that I was forced to make far too often. Moreover, had I been someone will less support, self esteem, or better things to do, I may have given in. The fact is that if a young man like myself, who has everything in the world going for him, can come that close to making a life altering mistake, it can truly happen to anyone. Furthermore, as I have seen first hand in the lives of friends and loved ones, the talons of addiction are sharp and unrelenting. Once they have a hold of you they won't let go until you are either knocking on death's door or have already past the threshold. 

So the questions I would pose to policy makers are simple. Firstly, who are you protecting? What other cheap, readily available forms of opiate addiction management exist. What is it about kratom that gives it its "high potential for abuse." And finally; why criminalize a last means of survival for American addicts? 

Kratom is not our problem. Children aren't being found dead with needles full of kratom in their arms, and none of my friends have ever dropped out of school to start selling kratom. Opiates are the real enemy, and the proposed rescheduling of kratom is sure to be a counterproductive, and costly mistake in the fight against the very real and infinitely more dangerous prescription pestilence we find ourselves face to face with.

My name is Nathaniel Colbert, I am a 29 year old resident of the US.

Making kratom a schedule 1 drug is about the most ridiculous thing I've ever heard.  It's like the equivalent of making coffee a schedule 1 drug.

I have been using kratom for nearly 3 years.  I drink 4-6 cups of kratom tea every day, about the same amount of coffee I drink.  Like coffee, it helps me focus and gives me an often much-needed boost of energy.  Unlike coffee, it also helps ease my social anxiety.  Without it, I don't think I would have been able to return to college, at which I am currently studying pharmacology.

There must be hundreds if not thousands of herbal supplements as well as OTC medicines that are more dangerous than kratom, so I don't understand the proposed scheduling of a natural substance that has been used safely for thousands of years.

I can only speak for myself, but kratom is less addictive than coffee, it does not get you "high" and I don't think it has any abuse potential at all.

The EXTREMELY small number of deaths associated with kratom all included a combination of drugs. This cannot be used to justify any danger of kratom, and only speaks to the irresponsibility of those that recklessly combined drugs with kratom.  This, and many other excellent points indicating the ridiculousness of the proposed scheduling of kratom are summed up nicely in the Hogan Lovells letter to the DEA:

https://drive.google.com/file/d/0BwMPT92bOJKdZWM2bzlLeU5DdDg/view

In conclusion, kratom has greatly increased  my quality of life, and has helped me get back on track to becoming a productive member of society.  And not just me, but it has proved to be, for various reasons, a great benefit to thousands of people in the US alone. I cannot even conceive of the fact that I could become a felon for drinking an herbal tea.  It's no secret that the "War on Drugs" has been an absolute failure, and adding a natural substance that is safer than caffeine to the category of controlled substances that includes heroin and LSD is laughable, and another step in the wrong direction. The proposal to make kratom a schedule 1 drug defies common sense, logic, and scientific evidence.

So I implore you, please do not make kratom a scheduled substance. If you do so, you will ruin the lives of thousands of good American citizens.

Thank you.

I have severe arthritis (and little to no cartilage in both knees) and occasional back troubles stemming from the arthritis. 10 years ago, I lived outside of the United States (my husband is from the UK, we have sense moved back to the USA). During that time abroad, I gave birth to my son. I did not drive though walked everywhere - to the grocery store, to the shops, to bring my child to school.  Month after month, the arthritis and the damage to my knees became extensive and mobility became excruciating. Codeine IS available in England in low, over-the-counter 8mg doses(combined with acetaminophen or ibuprofen). What started as occasional and as needed, one or two every day or two, over the course of those 3 years, became up to 24 pills every day. Otherwise, the tremendous pain I was in, barely able to make it to the end of our street, would reduce me to tears. I ended up homeschooling my son for a year, because I just couldn't walk anymore.  We had made the decision at that point to move back to the United States. I brought with me a fairly large supply that I hoped to wean myself from slowly...  which I did...  but the withdrawals were severe, the sickness was horrendous, and my pain levels shot through the roof. I turned back to opiates, in any way I could find them. That method was poppy pods and the tea made from them. It was my only alternative and steady source. My consumption was staggering - just to get to a level where I could function in anyway.  I was, at my worst,  using almost a measuring cup full of ground pod in the tea - every day. I was hooked again and this time it was far worse. I tried quitting numerous times, but the sickness from the withdrawals always made me stumble and go back to the poppy tea. I was desperate. I was ashamed, I was fearful. I was disgusted with myself.  Two years ago I finally had surgery to help alleviate some of the more serious health concerns that I had been living with. I needed to get my life back. I had a husband, a son.  I needed to be able to be there for them.  I read an article about Kratom years ago, but I always passed it off as a gimmick.  But enough was enough.  About a year and a half ago, I gave in and ordered a small amount from a local herbal store (online) and gave it a try. I had begun tapering off the opiates about a week prior and was feeling horrible - stomach cramps, loose bowels, muscle spasm, headaches, nausea...  The Kratom arrived, I tried a teaspoon in warm water. It was disgusting. Completely disgusting tasting....  but after about 20 minutes, I began to notice that the muscle pain (from the opiate withdrawal) started to subside. The stomach cramps lessened.  Interesting. I took another teaspoon the next day. Choked it down. DID NOT TAKE MY USUAL OPIATE DOSE....  barely any withdrawal symptoms. I was amazed. I quit the opiates cold turkey at that point. Within a week I had stopped opiates, felt little to no sickness, and noticed that my knee joints felt pretty good.  I did NOT experience any kind of 'high'...  more of an energy as one would feel after a few cups of coffee.  I doubt anyone, because of the taste, would flock to kratom for any kind of a high...  it really does taste bad. I no longer need walking aids and my mobility is getting better every day.  I still take about a teaspoon of kratom a few times a week, as needed.  Thankfully, I don't need more -because after all this time, I still have not gotten used to that taste.  yuck.  But I am grateful for the freedom it has given me the fact that it is a LEGAL supplement.  My fear is that if this avenue was denied me at my lowest point - where I'd be right now.  And for the millions of people that struggle every day with similar addictions could be denied the same relief as I have found.  Every day, so many people are struggling with addiction, suffering with severe pain, dealing with so many issues - but simple, basic, NATURAL relief is being denied them. To Whom It May Concern,

I am writing today to express my concerns with the DEA's plan to move Kratom into the schedule I category of illegal substances. Making this plant and its constituents schedule I, effectively makes it impossible for legitimate researchers to discover and develop valuable medicines from Kratom that could benefit the lives of millions.  This is not a sensible approach to regulating this plant.

Current peer reviewed studies on Kratom and its constituents have shown that Kratom has no acute toxicity, displays powerful antioxidant and antibacterial properties, assists with drug and alcohol withdrawal symptoms, contains several oxindole alkaloids which have exhibited potent immunomodulation properties, and even contains constituents that have exhibited anti-cancer properties.   A brief search in any scholarly database will present hundreds of peer reviewed studies and clinical trials that can attest to the medical potential of this plant.

Although I am not a user of this plant myself, I come from a community that has been hit by the opiate crisis and have lost friends to this horrible epidemic.  Kratom is helping people free themselves from the scourge of opiate addiction and it is criminal to take this valuable tool away from them.

In summary, the current proposed legislation places the medicinal herb Kratom and its constituents in the Schedule I category which is reserved for highly dangerous, addictive drugs that have NO medical value.  The medical literature has proven Kratom and its constituents to be quite the contrary; a useful, safe, medicinal plant that has been used for thousands of years without incident.  Kratom does not present a significant threat to human health or safety, when compared to legal substances such as alcohol, tobacco, Rx medications, Tylenol, or even coffee.  

Thank you for your consideration

Ladies and Gentlemen: 

I am writing this letter to protest the possible scheduling of kratom or its active ingredients. Mine is a personal story, not based upon large scientific studies, but rather on my own experiences with the supplement.

First, I should say that I am a 62 year old grandmother, not a "kid" looking for the next cool designer drug.  I suffer from several chronically painful conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis resulting in (among other things) bone spurs on my cervical spine, and fibromyalgia.  I have undergone a total knee replacement of my right knee. 

Until I discovered kratom, my only choices consisted of moving up to opiate painkillers, or continuing to try and get through my days in unrelenting pain. While researching options for pain control, I came across a reference to kratom, and turned my reading in that direction.  Honestly, it sounded too good to be true and I've been around long enough to know that when something sounds too good to be true, it usually is.  Pain relief from a natural source without horrid side effects and without the nearly inevitable addiction?  Sure.  Go ahead and pull my other leg while you're at it.  

However, as more and more offerings by conventional and holistic medicine (physical therapy, meditation, etc.) proved ineffective, I kept circling back to kratom.  I finally decided to try it out, anticipating (as has been my experience with certain other herbal supplements) absolutely no effect. 

I have never been more wrong. Just two teaspoons of powder per day, mixed with water, banishes my pain, allows me to move my head freely, allows my hands to have the flexibility needed to spin yarn and knit, allows me to walk and/or to ride my stationary bike to strengthen my knee, and vanquishes the fatigue that chronic pain causes.  I don't know if the lack of fatigue is the natural result of not being in pain, or if it is an effect of the kratom itself, but I don't really care, either.  

Unlike opiates, I do not detect CNS symptoms (feeling 'high', intense sleepiness, etc.).  It does not make me itch all over, and does not make me constipated. There do not appear to be any bad interactions with the other prescription drugs I take for high blood pressure and high cholesterol, as my checkups have shown no change for the worse in my blood test results or blood pressure.  

I see this as no different from using turmeric or ginger, rather than prescription drugs, to reduce inflammation.  Please do not force me to choose between opiate use or nearly debilitating pain when there is a dietary supplement available to do the job.

To Whom It May Concern:

I am against the ban on kratom. I do not believe it should be a controlled substance.

I will highlight kratom's medicinal value, as well as consider it's abuse potential.

I have suffered from chronic pain in my back and hips since September 2014. My pain is bad enough to prevent me from enjoying all of the activities I once did. However, the underlying cause is not severe enough to warrant surgery at my young age. While I am not currently using kratom, I did use it for a short time  about a month. It had a mild positive effect on pain, and fewer negative effects when compared to pharmaceutical opioids. In fact, the only negative effect I experienced was temporary nausea when I first consumed it, which was from ingesting the leaves with the tea instead of filtering them out. With multiple cups of kratom tea, I was never mentally impaired.

I stopped using kratom because managing pain through a prescription is more affordable and convenient at this time. However, it is good to know I have a natural option should I need it. Unfortunately, scientific study has not been exhaustive, and scheduling will make that even more unlikely. So far, evidence suggest that "kratom, kratom extracts, and molecules isolated from kratom can alleviate various forms of pain in animal models." [1] Combined with a multitude of anecdotal evidence, it would be foolish to say that kratom is of no medicinal value. Mild pain relief is still pain relief. 

Now for an observation regarding abuse potential:

I work for a helpline that takes calls of people suffering from substance abuse issues. A common scenario that I hear is that a person has become dependent on a dangerous substance, such a heroin, because a safe alternative to pain relief is not made available. Perhaps if an herbal supplement like kratom was readily available, and more people knew about it, a percentage of lives would be saved from the physical, psychological, and legal heartache caused by dangerous drugs. Will some people abuse it? Yes. Some people abuse alcohol, but prohibition often hurts more than it helps. 

In closing I ask that the DEA will allow the American people to make informed decisions as adults when it comes to things that can do more good than harm, while you focus efforts on the substances that are doing more harm than good. Let kratom be an unscheduled herbal supplement. 


[1] Prozialeck WC, Jivan JK, Andurkar SV. Pharmacology of Kratom: An Emerging Botanical Agent With Stimulant, Analgesic and Opioid-Like Effects. J Am Osteopath Assoc 2012;112(12):792-799.

documents.commentText:
Kratom has saved my spouse's relationship with our child and myself.

My spouse is seriously ill with a genetic condition (Ehlers Danlos Syndrome / EDS) that has led to severe complications including adhesive arachnoiditis. Both these conditions cause extreme acute pain that cannot be cured and has been described by doctors as "worse than cancer pain." 

Many EDS patients in similar conditions are prescribed high opioid dosages.  However, my spouse has a negative reaction to opioids that causes them to become extremely angry and aggressive.  When she was on Oxycontin briefly, our daughter said  "Dama has changed--she's not the same person anymore."   Even though I'm her sole care-taker, I briefly considered ending the relationship rather than risk it becoming abusive for myself or our kid.

Instead, my spouse swore never to take opioids again, even though the doctors haven't been able to find any other medication that successfully blocks pain from this condition (we went through almost all the opioid family drugs). She became entirely bedbound, and would often spend all day in the dark, frequently weeping.  She could hardly have a place in our child's life.  

Then my research turned up kratom, and we decided to start with a low dose and slowly work our way up.  The change is miraculous. Kratom was more effective than the opioids and instead of having a negative impact it was mood elevating and helped her be cheerful even in the face of continued pain (nothing that leaves you conscious will really stop this level of pain).  On Kratom, my spouse has been able to transition to using a wheelchair and even occasionally walking.

When the ban seemed imminent, my spouse and I had a very serious conversation about quality of life. She says that without kratom, she will likely chose suicide -- and to be honest, I support her in that.

But I can say with no hesitation that if kratom is banned, we would try to find a way to continue using it. I don't want my child to lose her parent, any more than I want my spouse to live in agonizing pain and distress.  Blocking kratom may cost my family a life -- or maybe it will just turn us into criminals who have to rely on dangerous street sources! How is either outcome preferable to keeping it safe and legal?

I would welcome regulation that required kratom to pass basic certification for purity and percentages, or that required buyers to be sent information about safe usage.  But I beg you not to prioritize the desire to police recreational users at the cost of killing disabled users.

First and foremost I do not advocate the recreational use of m.speciosa or any other herbal supplement that is psychoactive or mind altering.
When evaluating a medication for public use as in "over the counter" analgesics it is imperative,imho, to consider the physiological potential for tolerance and more importantly, withdrawl symptoms.It is my opinion that m.speciosa does not have significant withdrawl symptoms associated with its abrupt discontinued use.
In comparison the drug ibuprofen 600mg presents with no evident withdrawl symptoms. M.speciosa has minor withdrawl symptoms similar to a very mild cold or mild flu lasting 1 to 2 days. At the other end of the spectrum we have the narcotics hydrocodone and oxycodone which produce withdrawl symptoms so debilitating that the patient is unable to function for days or sometimes weeks without another dose of large magnitude.
In Florida the drug hydrocodone was recently elevated from a class 3 to a class 2
because of its high rate of abuse and ,imho,its addictogenic characteristic.
People can overdose on hydrocodone,once addicted the patient has lost the ability to choose. I applaud the lawmakers in Florida for rescheduling the narcotic hydrocodone, It was a step in the right direction.
On the other hand my experience with m.speciosa has been positive. It is not a synthetic drug as it grows on trees of the coffee family. In its organic purified form the potential for benefits, imho,far outweigh the potential negative consequences. I have only studied m.speciosa for 2 years thus the long term ramifications of its continued use is unknown to me. I am not aware of anyone overdosing or becoming addicted ,in the classical sense,to this drug. Personally I drink coffee every day, I enjoy the morning cup of "joe" every day. Am I addicted to caffeine?  Maybe a little bit because on days that I can not get to Starbucks the girls at my office think I'm a more grumpy.
The most positive aspect of obtaining m.speciosa legally in shops or over the Internet is,imho,the striking ability of this herb to effectively and rapidly allow the opiate addict to completely detox himself from whatever opiate is the cause. I have seen addicts who are trying to get clean use m.speciosa in place of methadone to successfully detox themselves. Don't get me wrong here, I'm not advocating m.speciosa as a panacea for ridding the world of opiate addiction.
However, I feel strongly that the efficacy of this herbal remedy,in its organically purified form has tremendous upside potential. I am fairly certain that with the right education and exposure this herb could possibly save the average opiate addict from years of a miserable existence. M.speciosa has been around for thousands of years, why is it that the Western world is just now learning about its uses? 
Finally I believe that there is still much to be learned regarding this and many related herbal medicaments. I do not believe that classifying this to a class 1 narcotic would benefit anyone except maybe the manufactures of oxycodone,hydrocodone, and possibly farmers in Afghanistan. 
I hope this helps to shed some light on the current situation. My motive for writing this is from my two young sons ages 9 and 11. I hope they grow up in a state where they never lose the power of choice. I hope they make good choices,I hope they never smoke cigarettes. I hope they play baseball for the Cubs.
We have never had it so good and the best is yet to come. That's all.

documents.commentText:
I am writing to express my opposition to a possible Kratom ban. 
Banning Kratom would be a deleterious event for society as I've witnessed the benefits this plant has had for those suffering with chronic pain and addiction to heroin/prescription opiates. I speak with perhaps a somewhat higher level of understanding on the matter than most. I'm a medical provider who was trained at Cornell Medical College. I've practiced medicine in the ER as well as other capacities as an Air Force officer. I've had the unique experience of working in a methadone clinic treating heroin addiction. I've studied kratom in depth for years. My knowledge on this plant exceeds the capacity of this forum, but I wish to stress my belief that the FDA/DEA has greatly exaggerated the threat this plant poses. Furthermore, it has been suggested that a Kratom ban is rooted in the interests of pharmaceutical firms seeking to capitalize on the alkaloids found in this plant, namely mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine. Word on the street and in news outlets is that a drug is coming to market with the same active alkaloids as found in Kratom and for this reason the FDA (likely under influence from those who stand to benefit financially) intends to advocate for a ban which will likely only result in a mass migration of former heroin and other opiate abusers back to their previous drugs of abuse. I make this claim rather confidently as I'm "in the trenches" treating patients and have whitness the scope and severity of America's pill addiction. I've met patients who have struggled for years to beat their opioid addictions. Many have required pharmacotherapy under the direction of a clinician. Sadly, many have failed to beat addiction despite specialist intervention and have resorted to drug-seeking tactics at the ER to "score" a script for opiates. This trend has resulted in clinicians fighting back with increasingly judicious prescriptive tendencies. As a result we are seeing a surge in heroin use, which has become more easily obtainable to the addict than prescription drugs. 
Interestingly, I have seen people overcome opiate addiction, after all else has failed, with the use of Kratom. I've also witnessed the benefits Kratom provided to people suffering from chronic pain and other illnesses. But, above all, I wish to stress the benign nature of this plant, its paucity of adverse effects and it's lack of ability to cause consumer harm. 
By far the most common cause of death from opiates results from respiratory depression. Kratom however does not cause respiratory depression nor death. Kratom's alkaloids had been known to act on opioid receptors. However, two studies published recently by researchers at Columbia University and Memorial Sloan-Kettering have indicated the action of opioid receptor activation in Kratom entails a pathway involving a G-protein pathway rather than the pathway involving a protein called beta-arrestin-2 (as in traditional opiates). This alternative pathway is what accounts for Kratom's lack of respiratory depression and adverse effects. This very important distinction must be understood by the DEA as it deliberates regarding Kratom. 
The DEA states they're "aware" of 15 deaths related to Kratom. However I have been unable to find any proof that any deaths have ever been attributed to Kratom - it's as if this claim has been made anecdotally. In fact, in at least 14 of the deaths, other drugs/illegal substances where found on toxicology reports. Also, many of the other reported dangers of Kratom as per the FDA/DEA are either grossly exaggerated or simply false.  Dr David Kroll, a pharmacologist and medical writer, has stated that it is "going overboard" to classify Kratom as a dangerous drug. "Kratom being lumped in with other opioids is both unfair and unscientific," he says. "It glosses over the subtleties of how the main chemical in kratom actually works."
 I want to again mention that records indicate in 14 of the "Kratom deaths" other drugs/substances were present. It is unfair and deceitful of the DEA to justify a ban on Kratom based on these cases when association clearly did not equal causation.
I have yet to encountered a patient who overdosed on Kratom. I have however encountered patients who overdosed on legal drugs such as alcohol, Tylenol, caffeine, dextromethorphan (DXM) and benzos. Interestingly, kava, a legal herb sold at Walmart, is known to activate benzo receptors like Xanax and should perhaps be banned before Kratom. Additionally, DXM is legal yet often abused for its effects similar to PCP and ketamine and has also been shown to activate opioid receptors at high doses. 
Simply put, kratom, has a long history of safe use and does not represent a danger to public health. I believe a Kratom ban will only result in a rise in heroin and prescription drug abuse. 
For more information on the safety of Kratom please reference the link below. 
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3670991/

Thank you!

Im a 72-year-old mostly retired Philosophy professor. I found out about kratom by accident in a boutique while on vacation in Sedona, AZ in June 2016. I saw a packet of it in a display case. I had never heard of it and asked the sales clerk what it was. I was told that it was a legal, mild opiate-type botanical that had interesting psychoactive action, having both stimulant and depressant or sedative effects. Intrigued, I bought a small packet, tried it, and liked it. I then read a lot about it, bought some more on line, found a reasonable dosage size, and have been using it ever since.

I do not use kratom to achieve any particular medical benefit, but its analgesic and stress-relieving effects are clearly evident in my experience. My personal use of kratom is analogous to moderate and responsible use of alcohol. I ingest 5-6 grams of kratom once a day about three times a week, typically Friday-Sunday evenings. I find its effects to be pleasurable in the form of a smooth sense of relaxation, calm, being stress-free. I feel this as a kind of blissful full body experience that lasts 3-5 hours, and with no hangover or negative aftereffects. The only side effects I have experienced are a mild loss of balance and one occasion of vomiting after taking too much. The former side effect is fairly easy to compensate for with simple attention, and the latter is instructive in learning ones proper personal dose. I notice no cognitive decline when under kratoms influence, and apparently others see no evidence of cognitive decline in me either. Interestingly, as a former moderate drinker of alcohol, my wine consumption has been reduced by about 95% since I started taking kratom. And unlike with alcohol, there is no noticeable immediate toxicity from kratom in my experience with it.

It is important to acknowledge that kratom can be harmful if abused by taking too much, too often, and/or compounding with other substances, especially other opioids or alcohol. However, the vast majority of those who use kratom appear to do so responsibly. Therefore, that responsible majority should not be prohibited from acquiring kratom because a few harm themselves by improper and irresponsible abuse of it. Most current evidence suggests that kratom has beneficial and harmless effects when used reasonably and responsibly. So until there is definitive scientific evidence that kratoms harm to individuals or society outweighs its benefits, kratoms alkaloids should not be classified as Schedule 1 drugs, thereby prohibiting its acquisition by responsible adults. Moreover, the Federal Government needs to respect individual rights and personal liberties and shy away from engaging in state paternalism. Such governmental paternalistic actions in the past have shown again and again that they dont work, create unregulated criminal black markets, and end up causing more harm and expense than the substances being prohibited.

Thank you for your attention to my thoughts on this matter.

Benefits are real for some people with serious conditions. Some veterans would suffer on other painkillers that pose a worse addiction potential and worse side effects. As you should know, Tylenol is responsible for a far greater amount of poison control center calls, and hundreds deaths from overdose. Acetaminophen, the active ingredient in Tylenol, accounts for 100,000 calls per year to poison control centers, not even close to the 660 that kratom received in five years. Kratom does not seem to be responsible for one single death in which it was the sole substance used. I believe it would be a mistake to schedule kratom the same as heroin because it DOES have medicinal value worth investigating. Obviously research on Kratom will have a far greater barrier to jump if it becomes a schedule 1 drug.
It makes me and thousands of other Americans worried about corruption between large pharmaceutical companies and The Drug Enforcement Administration because kratom is a naturally occurring substance, thus cannot be patented, thus cannot make as large of a profit due to competition. When was the last time we cut restrictions on freedoms in this Land of the Free? The liberty for someone to medicate themselves should be available. All I see now is more anti-science, uncalled for acts of authoritarianism. Also, why would you want to imprison American veterans that use kratom to ease them through their day? Many of these self-medicated people are mothers and fathers to children that need them to care of them. I would be appalled at the irresponsibility of a government to think of power and punishment before its people's well-being.

I have used kratom less than a dozen times and never more than once every two weeks. I consider my use of kratom responsible. I learned that it is the best herbal remedy for lowering my anxiety. I did not witness any potential for addiction. However, I did get a little drowsy. I also take Benadryl (for allergies) and that also makes me drowsy so I am used to the feeling. Both still accomplish what they are intended to accomplish. The benefits outweigh the drawbacks. It should also be noted that kratom is not an opioid or a narcotic or any drug that gets you "high." The only purposes I have used kratom for are first dates, job interviews, and in a new settings with new people when my anxiety is at its highest. Kratom really did aid me in easing up to perform better during those incidents.
Unfortunately, my state seems to be one of the worst for opioid addiction and resulting overdoses. I have known many family members of friends and neighbors of friends. Kratom have been shown to act as a means to for opioid addicts to ween off dangerous opioid addictions. It sounds like this is well worth not making this medicine a schedule 1 controlled substance simply for the sake of the livelihood of Americans with substance abuse disorder, a major modern issue. If kratom could save just 1 opioid addict from addiction in all of the United States, wouldn't it be worth keeping around, realizing that there is no confirmed data on one single death from kratom alone? It seems logical to me to give these people a chance.
I am an American. You are an American. That addict down the street is an American. It is our responsibility to help them, not imprison them for trying to save their own lives. Kratom is not produced in meth labs. It grows from the Earth. People have to care for it and cultivate it in order to use it for whatever benefit. I have no power to help these people. All I can offer is this comment. Please consider the facts before making a decision. This entire essay came from memory except for the statistics which were the only items added after writing. I am in the middle of studying for finals and I have done my research on kratom months ago. Have you?

References

documents.commentText:
November 28, 2016

To the DEA,

I would like to share my thoughts about, and make my personal plea for the continued public availability of Kratom (Mitragynine speciosa) as a dietary ingredient for the relief of chronic pain, based on observations of my wife and her relief from some of her disabling health issues through the use of Kratom.

Over the past seventeen years, my wife has seen a major decline in her lifestyle related to serious chronic pain caused by multi-level spinal degeneration, a related five-level cervical fusion, and autoimmune inflammation issues. Once an active member of our extended family, the local community, our church, and working as a public relations specialist for local school districts, she's seen her interactions in the world shrink as her body continually fails her. 

Frustratingly, on top of her disabilities, she has the additional burden of being allergic to a broad range of painkillers and related medicines that might be used to treat her symptoms. She's been left without any effective pain treatments that do not leave her breaking out in rashes. The only alternative physicians have offered to prevent these breakouts is to prescribe simultaneous antihistamine treatments that over-sedate her, leaving her unable to drive and function out of the home. Because of this, she has chosen to live in pain rather than be held back, staying somewhat active while quietly suffering. A woman of faith, she believes that she must not give up despite her troubles. 

Through the constant pain, my wife uses all of her efforts to stay healthy, exercise daily, and follow through with complicated physical therapy regimens to maintain her ability to function somewhat independently. Recently through her own research she learned of Kratom, and began careful personal trials to see if she would be allergic to it (she has a broad range of food allergies as well). Despite the awful taste, she has consistently received an observable reduction in pain, elevated energy levels, and she's been able to reduce her intake of two opiate pain medicines. 

She's taken 5 teaspoons of Kratom daily for the last six weeks, and on the NRS-11 Pain Scale, she has seen temporary relief (lasts 3-4 hours) of up to two points (from a 5 or 6 down to a 4 or 3). This Thanksgiving, we were able to invite family to our home for dinner for the first time in seven years. In previous years we had to decline because of the persistence of her pain and the unpredictability of her energy to participate.

As a 56 year-old public school teacher, I've seen firsthand the dramatic effects of opiate and heroin use even in suburban and rural communities. I understand that our government feels an urgency to do something to push back against this epidemic. Regardless, Mitragynine is not an opiate and is clearly difficult to abuse by its nature. Mitragynine has proven to be of benefit to a large number of people both here and abroad, much like my wife has found. Its my belief any that dramatic restrictions or reclassification could hinder research and irreparably harm many who find it effective. Instead of punishing those who find real and current benefits from Kratom like my beloved wife has, perhaps other actions would benefit our population as a whole. I believe that Kratom should continue to be legal for supplemental and alternative treatment use by those who receive benefit from it, and I highly encourage further clinical research into its potential benefits. If Kratoms legality is rescinded with a Schedule 1 assignment, this treatment would ultimately be removed from my wifes efforts to manage her chronic pain.

RE: Docket No. DEA-442W - my comments

I'm not entirely certain that this comment will ever truly be read or considered, but with everything this substance has done for my husband and I, I cannot in good conscience allow the comment period to end without throwing my two cents into the pot.

My husband and I have a myriad of health problems both mental and physical. He has a curved spine which causes him any level of pain from dull persistent ache to shooting, debilitating stabs under the shoulder blade. This condition is untreatable except with use of opioid prescription pain management. This constant pain and consequent use of hydrocodone slowly turned him into an addict before age 17. He overdosed twice and attempted suicide once as an opiate addict. He had been abandoned by all friends and family in his life. With nowhere to go, he lived for various lengths of time in his truck with no home to speak of.

It was his eventual suicide attempt, subsequent hospitalization, and abandonment by his family that provided the impetus for him to seek a better way. He found out about the substance we've all come here to try to save - Mitragyna speciosa -- "kratom". Kratom not only allowed him to ween himself off opioid painkillers after seven years of daily use, it allowed him to hold a job consistently for the first time in his life. Quitting opiates left him with constant back pain that would grow so unmanageable that he would be unable to leave his bed or move at all. Kratom got him up and back to work after falling through the cracks of society for nearly his entire adult life. Kratom saved my husband's life. I owe the greatest gift I have in this world to this substance. Had it been a Schedule I drug when my husband was trying to taper his opiate use, he would never have pursued the option. He likely would have died an opiate addict like half a million other Americans from 2000 to 2014.

My husband hasn't touched a prescription pain killer in three years now. He has never been treated for addiction. He has never had the traditional rehabilitation experience. He saved himself with two 3 gram doses of kratom every day. This dose was enough to stop him from seeking opiate relief for his pain and withdrawals and does not impair his cognitive ability or attention. He has now at 24 held a full time job longer than a year for the first time in his life. We met just months after kratom allowed him to move his life past opiate addiction and a likely imminent early death. He is a strong, dedicated man, and the love of my life. I would never have been allowed the privilege of sharing my life with him had kratom been illegal, because my husband would almost certainly have succumb to addiction.

Now I will share my own side of this story. I am 21 years old and have struggled with severe major depression, generalized anxiety disorder, and social anxiety disorder since age 15. I haven't had health insurance in many years -- not since I was 11 and my father was put out of work by a disabling injury. Treatment for my mental health has come entirely from a series of charity organizations and crisis stabilization units. From the health department I was tossed back and forth between several Catholic clinics and sliding scale facilities attempting to find a single place that would give an uninsured minor psychiatric care. After several referrals to sliding scale psychiatric facilities became dead ends (most will not treat anyone under 18), a physician's assistant agreed to start me on bupropion XL. After desperately seeking treatment for nearly a year, I was given relief. For a few days I was reminded how bright life could feel. And, just as it has been with every psychoactive medication I've been prescribed since, the relief died away as quickly as it had come. Over the following years I was put on almost every SSRI, SNRI, tetracyclic, and anticonvulsant on the market. When all of these options had finally failed to make even a dent in my symptoms, I failed out of two colleges, suddenly lost sight in my left eye, was told I'd likely be diagnosed with MS in the next 5 years, and found myself in the ER unable to mitigate my panic attacks any longer. From there I was placed under involuntary psychiatric hold - a "1013" here in Georgia - and transported to a crisis stabilization unit for a mandatory three days.

All of the people with these issues have way more reason to fight for kratom than I do.  However,  I am here to defend myself as well as defend them.  

I'm 46 as of tomorrow.  I've been married 19 years and have a beautiful 16 year old daughter.  I work as a department manager at a well known retailer.  I have been with this company for 4 years. I am a seamstress as well.  

I will first mention that I have had a previous dependence on opiates after an accident 14 years ago where I fell onto my head into the street. It caused a pinched nerve in my lower back that caused my left hand to lose all strength.  I couldn't pick up a pen to write my name.  I had severe lower back/ hip pain and unbearable headaches.  I'm certain that it slightly affected my memory and ability to focus.  I really never felt the same after that.  I would like to note I never took any drugs. Never even smoked marijuana in high school/college. I was never around it and never had the desire to try. 

Six months after my accident I began having severe pain in my lower back. 2 years of pain management and several increases in vicoden/muscle relaxers later I was tired of the cycle and decided to stop taking the medication but I found myself unable to stop. 3 years later I found out about suboxone and spent nearly 3 years on it.  After my doctor retired and not wanting to go 6 months on a waiting list, I quit the suboxone in an uncomfortable 2 weeks withdrawal period.  I haven't touched any medication since then.

 My coworkers can attest how bad it gets so they give me repreive. I have had to leave work and go to urgent care because of it.

Since that day,  I have not taken a single allergy pill. Not one!  No Claritin, no Xyrtec, no Benadryl....no neti pot, no steroids and no antibiotics. I'm clear and focused and I believe it is because I'm no longer on the antidepressants.  I feel no panic attacks anymore which could get pretty severe.  The brain fog after my accident 14 years ago is gone. I feel like I did 20 years ago.  One tsp every morning and one before bed.  That has been my routine for 5 months.  I know how opiates work.  After some time, the initial dose isn't enough and you have to increase it.  And I know from experience, this happens very quickly.  I have had no desire to increase the amount of kratom I am taking.  Kratom has done nothing except improve my life.

My mother has acute arthritis in her back, scoliosis and  rhumatiod arthritis. There is no surgery for this.  She has always been tiny but Im watching her shrivel.  She now leans severely to one side and has lost so much weight. The doctors don't know how to help her so they give her medicine.  22 Medications to be exact.  She sees four different specialists and her medication is monitored closely but it has gotten so bad! She takes 3 pain medications but it makes her so tired that she cannot sTay awake. Not because of her physical ailments, but because of all the medication!  At this point with the possibility of kratom being banned, I cannot introduce this to her.  Strangely enough, she had mentioned reading about an herbal supplement that really sounded like kratom but she couldn't remember the name. I hope my testimony helps shed light on the kind of people who are benefitting in a positive way from kratom.  Please consider my story when making your decisions.

documents.commentText:
This substance, carefully managed, has worked wonders for me in two ways.  First, it helped me avoid a more serious dependence on opioid painkillers after a long-in-healing serious accident, and second, helped treat the pain that caused me to risk dependence when doctors consistently prescribed opioids, despite my concern that I was developing a tolerance.

To my knowledge, no deaths have been attributed to the presence exclusively of these compounds in the systems of any decedents, but obviously, more research is needed to explore the almost universal acclaim and intense preference, in terms of effectiveness and personal sense of risk, for kratom over opioids, according to the people who have used both to treat the very real issue of chronic pain.  These are people who are seeking to avoid addiction, not people seeking a high, so perhaps their voices merit your more studied and less spasmodic attention.  Methadone and buprenorphine sometimes help, but merely replacing more dangerous opioids with less dangerous opioids does not actually free the patient of opioid dependence, increasing significantly the risk of relapse (compared to the small number of people who get entirely opioid free, including a notable number of people who attribute their rare achievement in part to krartom).

So far, we have only ancecdotal information about kratom, but we know all too well and with grim detail the intense dangers of opioids and heroin, of the incredible medical and social scourge they are spreading across the country.  That scourge begins in many cases with ongoing, legitimate prescriptions, graduallly but inevitably building tolerance, and intentions no more devious than not to be in constant pain and to participate meaningfully in a productive and engaged life.  The data are both shocking and sobering; in the 30 minutes it took me to write this message, 20 more Americans have visited ER's for opioid overdose (CDC, 2016)--who knows how many more have died outside of the ER's, which many addicts (and their friends, when addicts overdose) are afraid to visit for fear of legal reprisals.    

Thus, not to investigate a potentially much safer and more effective alternative is, essentially, to endorse the continuation of that scourge, to which no policy measure so far introduced has proven effective, least of all those involving more intense enforcement and police actions.  That the DEA would be the agent of worsening this problem by thoughtlessly forestalling a potential solution is not only short-sighted and bitterly ironic; it's also detestable and tragic.

So, It is up to the DEA, now, to decide how many more addicts' deaths it is wiling to tacitly endore by prevenitng responsible research and regulation of kratom.  Think carefully this time, but recognize that as you do, people are dying.  Doesn't the government of the people, for whose protection the DEA exists, owe these highly endangered citizens every possible chance not to slide back into active addiction?  
 
Regulate this product, keep an eye on it, and do all you can to support serious medical research.  

Sincerely,.

ESC

This herb has helped me immensely in dealing with social anxiety and panic attacks; where once I had problems in social situations and going out in public, I now put myself out there like never before. As a result, my confidence and self-image have improved significantly over the years, but I continue to work at it. I am the one challenging and improving myself each day, but kratom is the tool that helps me do this by bringing on a positive mindset and reducing the impact that stress and negative emotions have on me. Physically, if I am not in the best shape of my life, I am close to it. Without this plant I wouldnt be able to do the daily weight training I do now, and I have changed my diet for the better since using kratom. I have seen a range of benefits to my mental and bodily health from using this plant; it has worked holistically to improve my life in so many ways. 
We assume that adults have the right to decide what, if anything, they ingest or put in their own bodies, even if those choices come with risks to the individual or society, as in smoking or drinking. This holds true in the case of kratom use as well, especially since this benign and salubrious herb does not even begin to compare with the addictive potential and social costs that are associated with tobacco and alcohol, respectively. If our society continues to allow adults to use alcohol and tobacco despite the significant negative impacts of their usage, there should be no question as to why they cannot also responsibly use a safe medicinal herb without the possibility of legal repercussions.  And yet, kratom is not in any way a threat to individual or personal health, certainly not like the two substances mentioned above.
The anecdotal and empirical evidence available proves completely contrary the notion that this herbwhich has been used safely by people in Southeast Asia for thousands of years is in any way an imminent danger to public health, as was claimed when the temporary ban was announced in late August 2016. That initial decision had as its main rationale a handful of fatalities associated with kratom use, but there is no actual proof that kratom caused any of the deaths in these cases. With all due respect to those who died, nearly every alleged kratom overdose fatality has occurred with the concomitant use of one or more pharmaceuticals/ drugs, rendering questionable the assertion that this plant had been responsible (Vradi et al., 2016). The fact is that kratom leaf in its natural form has not caused a single death over the millennia of its use in Southeast Asia, probably because its principal alkaloid, mitragynine, has significantly less potential to induce respiration depression than does morphine (Vradi et al., 2016). Kratom leaf has a highly complex phytochemistry, containing over 25 different alkaloids, and is also a good source of antioxidant catechinsincluding epicatechinwhich are associated with a wide range of physiological benefits (Duke, 1992). This plant should be thought of as a benign medicinal herb, not a dangerous drug. 
Drug policy decisions should be formulated on the basis of compassion and respect for human dignity; enforcing a draconian ban on a safe and effective botanical product and turning responsible users from all walks of life into criminals is an action that makes absolutely no sense from a moral, medical, or societal perspective. Thank you for providing the opportunity to express my views on this issue.
