For several years I struggled with an ever worsening addiction to opiate based painkillers. It ruined many aspects of my life, and the lives of those around me. Finally, after half a decade of being a slave to opioids, I managed to kick my addiction. It took moving all the way across the country to escape the environment and social group that was enabling my addiction, but I broke free of that addiction. 

Since then I have experienced chronic pain on a daily basis, and was in deep despair that I would have to suffer endlessly because I was unwilling to go back on opiate painkillers. I did research online and heard about Kratom. I went to a local shop, bought a small amount of Kratom powder, and took the recommended dose for my weight. Amazingly, it worked. Remaining vigilant for symptoms of physical or mental dependence on Kratom, I used it when my pain was unmanageable with over the counter pharmaceuticals such as ibuprofen or tylenol. 

Since discovering Kratom I have found relief for my chronic pain and it has kept me from being tempted to return to a destructive and abusive pattern of opiate painkiller use. Kratom has allowed me to take my life back and become a more productive and healthy member of society. I have a wife, a career, and enjoy hobbies such as hiking, swimming, and playing guitar: all of these things would not have been possible in the midst of an opiate addiction. 

On a more scientific level, I have experienced very little side effects associated with my use of Kratom, particularly compared to opiate use. Unlike opioid based painkillers Kratom has not caused me severe constipation, does not make me drowsy, does not interfere with sexual function, does not cause wild fluctuations in mood, and does not bother me to not take it every day. It has about the same addictiveness to me as a cup of coffee: sometimes you want it in the morning, but if you don't get it then you quickly move on and it is not constantly on your mind. 

As with any substance with an active ingredient, it is common sense to dose appropriately, just as you wouldn't take 50 tablets of ibuprofen for a headache. I would very much welcome a regulated way to purchase Kratom so that I know what I am getting, much in the same way marijuana and alcohol are regulated in my state (Oregon). I believe it is in the best interest of society to allow the sale of Kratom to continue, particularly with the scourge of opiate addiction killing so many people each and every day. Kratom has undoubtedly saved many lives, providing former opiate addicts a safe alternative to relapsing back into potentially fatal opiate abuse. 

The war on drugs has villified the desperate and the suffering for long enough; allowing responsible and regulated Kratom use for adults is a good step towards alleviating some of the epidemic of opiate addiction and contributes to a healthier and more productive society.

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern:

I am a board-certified emergency medicine physician, with practice
experience in multiple emergency departments in the Westen United States
throughout the past 6 years.

Prior to learning of the intended emergency scheduling of mitragyna
speciosa (kratom), my practice experience had always aligned with the
DEA's decision to add new chemicals to the controlled substances act.  It
has been my experience that when young adults, under the influence of the
latest designer drug, begin presenting to our emergency departments with
increasing frequency, an expedited updating of our drug legislation is in
order in the interest of public health.

While the relatively recent emergency scheduling of synthetic cathinones
("bathsalts") and synthetic cannabinoids ("spice"), left me nodding my
head in agreement with the policy decision, the proposed emergency
scheduling of kratom has conversely left me scratching my head.  Unlike
the aforementioned controlled substance analogues, which are synthesized
by illicit labs in an attempt to circumvent existing drug laws, kratom is
a natural leaf, which has been quietly consumed by people around the world
since the dawn of civilization.

In my work, I encounter overdoses of all types on an almost daily basis.
Over many thousands of patient encounters, I have yet to record a single
patient encounter that was the result of an overdose or adverse reaction
to kratom. The experiences of my colleagues, with whom I have discussed
this issue, mirror my own.

While I am not a primary care physician, and thus do not have long-term
relationships with my patients, I have also met a handful of patients who
have used kratom, and felt compelled to discuss this with me.  These
patients seemed to genuinely feel that kratom was an asset in their lives.
 Some patients were using the plant to assuage chronic pain, while others
were using it as a means to avoid using "harder" substances such as heroin
and alcohol.  Given the current nationwide epidemic of opiate abuse and
addiction, I feel this latter point is especially important.

Since the intended emergency scheduling announced at the end of August, a
significant number of patients have come forward, and  it has become
apparent to me that there is a significant number of diverse individuals,
ranging from wounded vets with PTSD, to the elderly with chronic arthritis
pain, who are quietly using kratom as a means to alleviate their symptoms.
 It has also become clear that these people are legitimately afraid that
the government will step into their lives, seeming out of the blue, and
leave them suffering.

On a personal note, I have both friends and family that use kratom for
different reasons, and this is what initially directed my attention to
this issue.  Speaking from the perspective of a friend and family member,
it has been experience that they have used, and continue to use, the plant
responsibility.  The proposed scheduling in August has caused them quite a
bit of consternation, which as ultimately compelled me to speak out
regarding my personal and professional experiences with kratom.

Given the long history of human use of this plant, and the large number of
Americans who feel it helps make their lives manageable, I feel FDA
regulation of plain kratom leaf as a dietary supplement with an age
restriction may be a reasonable path for the plant to take at this
juncture.  This would  allow the many individuals who derive benefit from
kratom to continue to use it without fear of criminal penalty, while an
ongoing and more comprehensive safety monitoring protocol can be
instituted.  Furthermore, proper regulation could possibly encompass
keeping kratom from being inappropriately sold in gas stations and smoke
shops as a "legal high,' where it is often sold as a concentrated alkaloid
extract that may even be combined with other unknown ingredients.

As both a concerned citizen and a physician, I would like to see our
federal agencies step in to help the individual citizen consumer, with a
focus on harm-reduction, industry regulation, product safety, and
education--without resorting to draconian drug policy and criminalization
of vulnerable populations.

Thank you for your time and consideration;

California Emergency Physician

**Due to the privacy concerns of patients, friends and family, I have
elected to post this comment in semi-anonymous fashion.   If anyone from
the DEA/FDA/dept of HHS would like to speak with me further regarding my
experiences, or to evaluate the veracity of this comment, please send an
email to public.comment.doc24659@tutanota.com**

Here are just a few of many reasons why banning Kratom would do more harm than good. 

1.  It would be illogical to make Kratom illegal, when two of the requirements for classifying a substance as Schedule 1 are that:  a.) the substance must be highly dangerous and b.) it must have no medicinal value.  Kratom cannot be directly linked to any deaths, as the few individuals who have died with Kratom in their systems, also had dangerous substances in their systems (such as Heroin).  Also, there have been more poison control reports for laundry detergent pods in the last seven months than there have been for Kratom in the last five years.  We currently do not know much regarding Kratom's potential medicinal value, but making it Schedule 1 would halt any research on Kratom, making us unable to learn of any potential medical benefits.  Making Kratom illegal, when dangerous substances such as cigarettes and alcohol remain legal, is downright hypocritical, and makes one question if money is the motivating factor in making these decisions. 

2.  The Center for Regulatory Effectiveness states that banning Kratom would be a violation of the US-Canada Regulatory Cooperation Council Agreement, since Kratom is classified as a permitted "National Health Product" in Canada.

3.  Banning Kratom could lead to higher rates of drug abuse and overdoses.  Alabama banned Kratom on May 10, 2016.  In the month following the ban, the number of overdoses in Birmingham, Alabama doubled. 

4.  A large number of people using Kratom are disabled.  Imprisoning these individuals, who have medical needs such as wheelchairs, walkers, etc., would be very expensive and inconvenient.

5.  Banning Kratom could cause the public to lose faith in our government and their decision-making process regarding substance scheduling.  There is a huge community of individuals who have taken Kratom without any ill-effects.  These individuals have spoken out against the potential ban and have shared their stories.  Following through with this ban would send a message to the public that our government isn't really listening, and isn't really looking out for our best interests.

In refrence to Docket No DEA-442W

To whom it concerns, 

My name is Jessica Dennis & I live in the wonderful state of Arkansas. I would like to share with you my Kratom story with the DEA & its regulators in hopes of reversing their mind set on this helpful plant. A little bit about me. I am a female in my mid 30's, I am a mother of two beautiful children , I am also a supervisor in a top Fortune 500 company. I am college educated & have over 11 years experience in the finical services industry. I am a responsible kratom user and have been for using kratom safely for about 6 years. I have never been in any legal trouble, never arrested, not even a speeding ticket on my record. In the 6 years I have used this wonderful plant, I have never gotten sick from it, overdosed after consuming it, nearly died,after using it or gone to the E.R. after using kratom. I do not abuse it & I only buy pure Kratom from online verifiable vendors who publish the authenticity of their products. 

I fully believe in the power of this plant. Before kratom I went from Dr. to Dr. in hopes they would prescribe me the perfect medicine for my mild depression & anxiety. Every few months I was at the pharmacy with a new expensive prescription.  I would wait the recommended time to allow my body adjust, and sadly each time was a disappointment . I still never felt like myself, I still felt like a zombie and unable to be their for my family 100%. I got sick and tired of being sick and tired, so one day as I lay sobbing on my bed preying for help, I went online and started searching for natural substances for depression. I came across Kratom and ordered my first supply and have never looked back. Kratom helped me feel like me again with no side effects or high cost prescriptions & Drs. visits. I was able to work , I was able to be 100% engaged with my family and friends, & I was able to wake up each morning happy , ready to take on a new day. Kratom is a safe, low cost, effective plant for millions of people battling aliments ranging from depression, anxiety, pain, skin disorders and addiction. 

Kratom, sadly has taken a hit for some stories in the media. Kratom has been safely used by its indigenous people for thousands of years. There is not one report (that I could find) showing kratom to be a direct result of death in a user. The reports and stories online are one filled with misinformation, those stories stating that Kratom is a result in ones death are false, those deaths were a direct result of dangerous drugs that were ingested by the user. I do agree that Kratom should have regulations around the purchase of Kratom. The responsible kratom users and the DEA want the same thing, to keep dangerous kratom out of the public. I know a lot of the reason Kratom has a bad name is from companies who mix substances in their kratom or vendors who market their kratom as a "legal high" or vendors who simply don't care and are trying to sell whatever they can to make money. My biggest suggestion would to stop allowing kratom to be sold in head shops (online only) & to make age restrictions on this product, in fact over 1/2 of responsible kratom consumers are over the age of 21. Lastly, creating a website or link that when the kratom community sees an irresponsible vendor or brand on the market, we can report it and they be investigate then shut down. The DEA & the Katom Community can work together to get bad companies off the market. Please do not punish the entire responsible kratom community for the irresponsible vendors. More people die from alcohol, tobacco & energy drinks then anything, but those products are still legal and sold.

In my closing statement, I would like ask the DEA to understand when evaluating the benefits vs the negative side effects , that the benefits outweigh the side effects 100 to 1. Kratom does help millions of Americans with chronic conditions, Kratom is safe, Kratom is affordable, Kratom has never cause a death, Kratom is not addictive, & Kratom deserves to stay available and legal to the millions of people including myself.  Thank you for taking the time to let me share my story.

Sincerely, 

Jessica Dennis

n March of 2012, I'd decided to quit drinking due to the inflammatory effects of alcohol on one's joints.  I work in the wellness industry, and am a developer/engineer for healthcare related software and spend between 10 - 15 hours a day typing on the computer. The diagnosis and symptoms of carpal tunnel combined with Raynaud's Syndrome made it very difficult to do my job and/or sleep.   My hands burn, ache, throb and become numb several times a day, despite maintaining an ergonomic desk setup.

I've never taken prescription pain medication and was using ibuprofen to try to manage the pain.  It wasn't helping and made the decision to talk to my doctor.  I explained that I'd quit drinking and because of that, did not want to take pain medication. Prescription pain medication is incredibly addictive and even more so for people who have quit drinking (or any other addictive substance). My doctor told me about kratom and explained the benefits. documents.commentText:
Dear DEA officials and members of congress,

Simply put, the last thing we need to be doing is scheduling even more substances. The scheduling system should have scientific merit, given its inception: something this agency has ignored for over 30 years. Attempting to emergency schedule a plant that has caused very little physical harm over decades of use, with clear medicinal benefits as purported by users, simply brings us back to the draconian beginning of the scheduling system.

As scientific evidence mounts for the use of cannabis along with therapeutic use of many of the schedule 1 psychedelic substances, a rash decision to classify another plant as schedule 1 is shortsighted and further induces distrust in the government and this agency. As information disseminates, it becomes apparent that the scheduling of drugs such as these had entirely ulterior political and racial motivations. Criminalizing drug possession, use, abuse and addiction has become another "entrepreneurial" route for corporations in the private prison system to abuse human rights in exchange for profit margins while the black market thrives on high prices and violence across the country and the world.

It is time to step up and do your part by paying attention to science, not hysteria, and leave kratom entirely alone. There are hundreds of species of plants that are extremely toxic and dangerous with psychoactive effects that are perfectly legal to grow and own, yet kratom is self-moderating in its own consumption making it almost impossible to have a strong adverse reaction to unless mixed with other illicit substances. Kratom has helped so many people ween off stronger prescription drugs, those legally obtained from our good samaritan pharmaceutical companies. Kratom has helped many ween themselves off street opiates, such as heroin, effectively HELPING your mission to rid our streets of drugs. Kratom, along with cannabis I might add, has also helped those with chronic pain avoid falling into the depths of prescription opiate addiction.  Kratom is not perfect and no drug is, everything has side effects, but Kratom is far from a bane of society. 

Keeping kratom legal will do exactly what this agency is designed to do: keeping people away from the drugs that truly tear families and communities apart. Driving kratom underground will simply perpetuate the never-ending war on drugs that only gets worse and never better.

Be on the right side of history and learn that American values are predicated on making decisions for ourselves that only affect ourselves.

"What if it was my son or daughter who talked of suicide every day?"  In reviewing and evaluating my comments I would like the kind people in the DEA to ask themselves that question in regards to taking action concerning Kratom.  

I want to offer the perspective of a parent whose son finally found relief from a horrible debilitating disease that has been nicknamed the Suicide Disease only to learn that Kratom, this God-sent relief giver, is in danger of becoming illegal.

My son has Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS), a rare disease that causes its victims to endure the highest level pain on the McGill Pain Index scale.  It is a 24/7 never-ending disease that has no cure.  It is a burning pain that victims describe as equivalent to draining the blood from the affected limb and replacing it with lighter fluid and then setting it on fire.  That only describes the physical side of the pain.  Since other people cannot see what is happening inside him they discount the amount of pain he suffers and some have actually said he is faking pain for some unknown reason.  It is easy to see why it is called the Suicide Disease because he suffers so much physically and has the added pain of being branded as a hypochondriac. He has been deserted by his friends and his wife who saw firsthand the constant and unrelenting effects of his pain and then left him because she couldnt bear to watch his suffering.  As almost always happens with this disease he has been left alone to suffer, and he frequently talks of suicide.

He sees doctors and specialists from multiple medical disciplines who try to help manage his pain, with only limited effectiveness.  Doctors prescribed many different drugs for him, but most only made him sicker.  The only real relief he gets is from OxyContin, but the prescribed amount barely reduces his pain from a 10 to about a 6 or 7 on a scale of 0 to 10 and the effect of the OxyContin wears off after only an hour or so.  He is allotted 3 per day by the prescription, so he is left with 21 hours of hellish pain out of every 24 hours.  He has no appetite and struggles to eat even a fraction of a plate of food.

Several months ago we learned about Kratom and the role it can play in pain management.  After some research we obtained some Kratom powder from a local shop and my son tried a small dose of one teaspoonful.  Within moments he went from having his usual pained expression on his face to playing with the dog, laughing and making jokes.  He ate a plate full of food and asked for a second helping.  The smile on his face and joy he was expressing brought my wife and I to tears as we saw our son experiencing and embracing life as we havent seen him do in the 6 years since he contracted CRPS following a foot injury.  This was not a drug high but a high on life high.

My son now takes 1 teaspoonful of Kratom 3 times a day and it has been a lifesaver for him, offering many hours of relief.  He is able to go days without the OxyContin just using the Kratom and the change in his life has been remarkable.  To be clear Kratom does not eliminate pain.  It is similar to prescription opioid pain medicine which can only reduce it and hopefully make it bearable, but Kratom has done far more than that.

As parents we of course have concern for Kratoms safety.  But from what we have read Kratom-related deaths seem to occur only when Kratom is combined with other drugs.  There have been a total of 15 Kratom-related deaths ever recorded vs. 18,893 prescription opioid pain medicine deaths in 2014 alone.  The entire number of Kratom-related deaths on record is approximately 0.08 percent of the number of prescription opioid deaths in 2014 alone.  Put another way that is a ratio of 0.00079 to 1.  10,574 people also died from heroin overdose in 2014.  Adding Heroin deaths to prescription opioid deaths the ratio becomes even more lopsided.

My sons experience is that Kratom has a built in mechanism to protect against overdosing.  It causes nausea and even vomiting if you take too much.  He has not experienced addiction or withdrawal symptoms when he doesnt take it.

I absolutely want more research on Kratom to unlock its full potential as a pain management tool.  Anyone who suffers from pain should have access to pain relievers that work and dont have the horrible side effects of prescription opioid medicine.  I simply ask that the DEA set a timetable for doing further research on how best to make Kratom available, and in the meantime to not schedule it pending the outcome of the research.

Kratom is a natural herbal supplement, not an opioid, and does not fit the criteria of harmfulness reserved for Schedule I substances. 

Schedule I drugs are supposed to have a high potential for abuse and harm and no medical use. My experience with Kratom has been that it greatly helps, not harms, individuals. I first heard about and began consuming Kratom in July 2016 after reading about and researching it online. I have mild depression and generalized anxiety disorder, which affect me on a day-to-day basis and make it difficult to focus on school work, be in social situations, or sleep well. When I found out about Kratom I had spent years looking for a viable herbal alternative to prescription anxiety and depression medications, which I am reluctant to take because of their negative side effects. Kratom is by far the best supplement I have ever found to help me with these conditions. With a daily low dose of Kratom (3-5 grams) consumed in a morning tea, I have had great success managing my depressive symptoms and keeping anxiety at bay. For the first time in my life I feel like I am functioning normally despite my conditions, and am able to productively deal with panic attacks instead of becoming overwhelmed by them. I am able to step back and calmly use psychological coping strategies before such episodes get the better of me. Kratom helps me relax, soothes my emotions, eliminates irritability, and improves my daily tension levels. My performance in school and the quality of my daily life have improved greatly. I am able to enjoy time with my husband and family, work productively, stay clear-headed, and combat creeping feelings of sadness. Kratom has also been a wonderful tool for helping me get a full night's sleep, similar to but vastly more effective than other supplements I've tried, such as melatonin. Kratom has not cured my conditions, only helped me deal with their symptoms while maintaining a productive, active, healthy lifestyle. I have noticed no negative side effects from my Kratom consumption. I am not addicted to Kratom, nor do I foresee any addictive potential in my consumption. Though I consume Kratom daily, I have stopped taking it for weeks at a time while travelling and experienced no withdrawal symptoms.

I am a responsible, high-functioning adult obtaining a six-year degree at one of the most prestigious institutions in this country. I am not interested in Kratom as a recreational substance, and believe it has little recreational potentialonly small doses are needed for help with symptoms, and though Kratom can produce a feeling of well-being, this is nothing like the kind of "euphoria" one would expect from an opioid. I can't imagine anyone using Kratom to get "high"an incredibly large amount would have to be consumed, which is impractical given the powdered leaf form this herb is available in, and effects would be very unpleasant (for example, nausea, sleepiness), discouraging this kind of abuse. An online survey of 6,150 Kratom consumers by Pain News Network and the American Kratom Association shows that the average Kratom consumer is a person over 40 looking for alternatives to pharmaceutical drugs that either didn't work for them or had side effects that were unbearable.

In my experience Kratom is safe, non-addictive, and extremely effective in relieving symptoms of mild depression and anxiety. It should remain legal, minimally regulated, and publicly available.

At that point, I was in very bad shape both physically and emotionally. I began looking into alternative and health-based approaches, such as changing my diet, eating organic, and taking some supplements. Over the years, I managed to hold my own even while living with often excruciating all-over body pain and debilitating fatigue. After being approved for disability and Medicare, I sometimes took pain medication, but infrequently because of the bad effects on my stomach. Then about two years ago, I heard about Kratom on a fibromyalgia website. Since in my experience, herbs and botanticals had been more helpful for me than drugs, I purchased some Kratom from a vetted online vendor (vetted by a group of Kratom users).
